Mr. Hoar had began to build a large & convenient wk-house for the Inds. near his own dwelling, which stood about the midst of the town,& very nigh ye  town watch house. This house was made not only to secure those Inds. under lock & key by night, but to employ them & set them to work by day, whereby they earned their onw bread , & in an ordinary way ( with gods blessing) would have lived well in a short time; but some of the inhabitants of the town being influenced with the spirit of animosity & distast agt. all Inds. did relish this settlemt. & therefore privately "setnt" crossed out sent to a cap. of the army (1)  that quartd. his compy. not far off at that time of whom they had experiend. that he wld. not be backward to put in execun. any thing that tended to disrest the pray. Inds., for this was ye same man that had formerly without order seized upon divers of the pray. Inds. at Marlbo., wh. brot much trouble & disquiet to the county of the Inds. & was a great occasion of their defection as hath been above declared. This Cap. accordly. came to Concd. with a party of his men upon the sabbath day into the meet. house where the people were convened in the worship of god & after the exercise was ended he spoke openly to the congregn. to this effect; "that he understd. that there was some heathen in the town committed to one Hoare, which he was informed were a trouble & disquiet to them, therefore if they desired it he wd. remove ym to Boston to wh. speech of his most of the people being silent

except 2 or 3 that encouraged him, he took as it seems the silence of the rest for consent, and immediately after the assembly were disba.d he went with 3 or 4 files of men, & a 100 or two of the people, men women & child.n at of? heels, & marchd away to Mr. Hoane's house, & there demand.d of him to see the Ind.s under his care, Hoane opened the door & showed them to him & they were all numbered & found there, the cap. unclear to Mr. Hoane that he co.d leave a corp.l & sol.ds to secure them, but Mr. Hoane ans.d? there was no need of that for they were already secured & were committed to him by order of the council & new.d? keep & secure them, but yet the cap. left his corp.l & solds. there, who were abusive enough to the poor Inds., by ill language. Next morning the cap. came ag.n to take the Inds. & send unclear to Boston but Mr. Hoane refused to delivr them unless he showed him an order of hte council but the cap. cl.d show him no other but his unclear to kill & destroy the eng. but Ms. Hoane said these were friends & under order but the cap w.d not be satisfied with his ans.r but commanded his corp.l forthwith to break open the door & take the Inds all away which was done accordingly, & some of the solds. plunder.d the poor creatures of their shirts shoes, dishes? & such other thing as the could lay their hands upon tho' the cap.n commanded ye contrary. Inds. at Deer I. some would have them all destroyd., others, sent out of the county. but some there were of more moderation, alledging that those Inds. & their ancestors had made a covenant with the Eng. about 30 years since, wherein mutual production & subjection was agreed and that it was expedient to search the records to see & considr. that agreemt. & whether those Inds. had broken ye Lawe or had deserved to be proceede agt. in so harsh & severe a manner, as some proposed; upon which motion the records were searched, & it was found upon record as follows. We have & by these presents do voluntarily & without any constraint or persuasion, but of our own free notion, put ourselves, our subjects, our lands. & estated under the govt. & jurisdn. of Mas. to be govnd. & protected by them according to their just laws & orders, so far as we shall be made capable of understanding them, & all do promise for ourselves & all our subjects, & all our posterity to be true & faithful to the Sd. gov't. & aiding to the maintainance there of, to our best ability. And from time to time to give speedy notice of any conspiracy attempt or cruel intention of any that we shall know or hear of agt. the same. And we do promise to be willing from time to time to be instructed in the knowledge of god. In witness whereof we have hereunto put our hands the 8th day of the 1st month 1643/4.

   certain quests. proposd. to the Inds. & their anss.

I. to worship the only true god who made Heaven & earth. 
Ans. We do desire to reverence the god of the Eng. because we see he doth better to the Eng. than other gods do to others.
II. Not to swear false.
(1) Ans. They say they know not what swearing is among them.(1)
III. Not to do any unnecessary work, on the sabbath day, especially within the gates of christn. towns.
Ans. It is easy to them, they have not much to do on any day, & they can well take their rest on that day. 
IV. To honr. their parents & superiors.
Ans. "Tis their custom to do so, for the inferiors to honr. their superiors.
V. To kill no man without just cause & just authory. 
Ans. This good & they desire to do so.
VI. To commit no unclean lust, as for instance, Adultery, incest, Rape, Sodomy, Bigamy or beastiality.
Ans. Tho' sometimes some of them do it, yet they account it naught.
VII. Not to steal.
Ans. They send to this as to the 6th Query.
VIII. To suffer their childn. to learn to read gods word, yt 
they may learn to know god aright, & to worship him in his way.
Ans. They say as opporty. will serve, & the English among them, they desire so to do. 
IX. That they should not be idle.
Ans. To which & all the rest they "ass" crossed out consented , acknowledging them to be good.
(1) It is for those to commit crimes who know them to be such.

The prey. Inds. confined to Deer I. are the people with whom the above written "grmts. were made, wherein subjection  & mutual protection are engaged, & these Inds. as is before declared, made discovery of what they kn"o"crossed out ew of the plottings & conspiracy of the eny. before the war began: also most readily & cheerfully joined with & assisted the Eng. in the war as is before in part touched & will more cly. appear in sequel of this discourse , also they submitted themselves to the laws of god & the Eng. govt., & desiring themselves & childn. to be taught & instructed in the chrn. relign. & have in all othr. points, so far as I know( for the body of them) kept & performed the  articles of their covenant above expressd,, when the genl. court had read & considered this agreemt., it had this effect ( thro' gods grace) in some degree to abate the clamors of many men agt. these Inds. 1675 . Before the genl. court adjournd.. which was not until the 28 of Feby., they had voted & concluded to raise an army of 600 men, to be put under the conduct of Maj. Thos. Savage, (1) as comdr. in chief; but (1)

Savage, & accordingly ordered that one John Curtis of Roxbury ( who was well acqd. with those Inds.) Shd. go down to Deer Isld. & choose out 6 of the fittest men for that service, which he did, & chose & bro't up with him 6 men whose names were James Quanapohit, Job Kattenanit ( those were the 2 Spies before mentioned) James Speen,  Andrew Pitimee, John Magus, William Nahaton. These were all principl. men, faithful & courageous, they were all willing & cheerful & joyful that they had this call & opportunity to serve the Eng. under Maj. Savage whome some of them had served under in the beginning of the war at Mount Hope. These 6 men being fitted & furnished with arms & other necessaries, they  were conducted to Marlbo. frm. whence the army was to march the first day of March, 1675-6. But before the army set forth from Marlboro there fell out a matter of trouble & disquiet to them, (1) occasioned by the motion of one of the caps. (1) of the army  of whom it hath been once & again declared that he was no lover of the pray. Inds. & because the matter referreth  to one of the 6 Inds. before named, now with the army; It seems pertinent to my purpose to declare it. Job Katt"a" crossed out enanit when he 
(1) Mosely.

95

returned fro the service he had done, as one of the spies obtained leave from the council to endevor to fulfill an agreemt. he had made with some of the Chrns. Inds. among the eny., particularly with Joseph Tuckapawilm minister of the Ind."s" crossed out  Ch., late at Hassanamesit & others to meet them in the woods about yose parts, & b"e" crossed out ring with them Job's 3 chldn. again to the Eng. In puruance of this order of the counncil Maj. Savage did ( with the advice & consent of Maj. Gen. Denison who was then at Marlboo. in order to dispatch away the army) give liberty to Job to go alone from Marlo. to the place appointed abt Hassananamesit, not above 12 miles distant, to meet his friends & childn., & to bring them in to the Army at the rendezvous at Quabage. Not long after Job was gone from Marlo. the Cap. aforesd. hearing of it, made a very great stir at the headquarters at Wm Ward's in Marlb. where the army was drawn up in a body in order to their march, & spake words reflecting greatly upon that action of sending away Job, alledging that  he would inform the eny. of the army's motion, & so frustrate the whole design. This fair pretence was managed in a mutinous manner by others of like temper & spirit, insomuch that the wisdom & prudence not only of Maj. Savage, but of Maj. Gen. Denison was much reflecd. upon. But they were fain to calm this storm by gentle means & soft words, &  forthwith ordered to send away Cap. Wa"r"crossed out dsworth & Cap. Syll, who offered themsel's with James Quannapohit to follow Job on horseback hoping to overtake him, & prevent that which

96
was feared. Accordingly they were speedily despatched to pursue Job, which had a tendency to compose & qualify the heats that were begotn, upon this occasion. But Wadsworth & Syll did not overtake Job, nor meet him till he was returned to the army, nor yet did Job meet with his friends, but found signs where they had lately been, for those poor creatures had shifted their quarters for fear, because the time was expired that job promised to meet them if he were admitted. But Job missing his friends, faithfully fulfilled his promise in returning to the army, whom he met upon the road about 20 miles westwd. of Marlo. & so proved himself an honest man, & that those suspicions of him were groundless. I conceive had this mutinous practice ( that so much reflected upon the chief commander of the army & authority of the council) been committed in some other parts of the world, it would have cost the author of it a cashiering at bast, if not a more severe animadversion, for it was an action against the order and good discipline of an army, for any private Cap.to animadvert ( in such a manner) upon the genls. actions, done with consideration & prudence. Those poor chr. Inds. before mentioned ( with Jobe's childn.) althoi. Job could not meet shew,yet were met by Cap. Benj. Gibbs & a small party of horse under his commd., who, scouting in the woods as the army were upon their march to Quabage took those poor creatures ( supposing they had  got

97

a prize) they were but 2 men, one very aged  + ) 3 women & 6 childn; the solds. that seized them took from the all those few necessaries they had preservedl as 2 rugs 2 brass kettles, some dishes &  a pewter cup that the minister* had saved, which he was wont to use at he administration of the sacrament of the Lords supper, being given him by Mr. Elliot for their use; in a word the solds. took all the little they had, & told many stories concerning them, that so ya might not return their things again. But god so ordered it that they hurt not their bodies, but brot them in to the genl. Savage at the rendezvous, wch understanding they were Job"e" crossed out 's friends, & his childn., he treated them civilly, & forthwith sent them with a guard back to Marlo. to be conveyd to Boston. But when the poor creatures came to Marlbo., they being quartd. there one night or 2 by the constables order, until an opportunity served to send them to Boston, there came some people of the town ( especially women) to yr quarters, some of whom did so abuse, threaten & taunt at these poor christns., & they being thereby put into great fears, that in the night the ministers * wife, & his eldest son, a lad of 12 yrs old, & another woman, a widow , that had carefully kept & nourished Job's children, with her daughter being 4 of the in all, escaped away into the woods; the ministers wife left a nursing infant behind her, with her husband, of abt 3 months old , which affliction was a very sore trial to the poor man, his wife & eldest son gone, & the poor infant, no breast to nourish it.

 Joseph Tuckapa^wilm                     + Navas

98
( I heard a prudential gentleman our Cap. Brattle of Boston, who was then at Marlbo., (for he heard the people's taunts & threats to them) say that he was ashamed to hear & see what he did of that kind, & if he had been an Ind.^& so abused he should run away as they did. Not long after, this poor Minister Joseph Tuckappawillim, & his aged father Navos a man of about 80 years old, both good chrisns., with three of 4 childn. of the minister's, & Job's 3 childn. were all sent to Boston, where they were kept a night or 2 & then sent to Deer Isld., where god provided a nurse ( among the Inds.) to preserve the life of ye sucking infant, & about 2 months after, his wife (1) was recovered & bro't in, by Tom Dublet(1), one of our messengers to the eny., but his eldest son before mentioned, died after he went away from Marlbo. with his mother con^ceived crossed out to [to have lost] so took his life thro' famine. The other widow, who went away at that time & her daughter were also recovered. This widow Job married afterward, not knowing how better to requite her love showd in nourishing & preferring this 3 childn. when they were among the enemies, & they now lived comfortably together, so that after all the troubles, sorrows, & calamities, this man Job underwent, (as we have before touched ) god gave him all his childn. in safety, & a suitable wife; & vindicated him from all the calumnities & aspersions cast on him & by good demonstrations cleared his integrity & faithfulness to gods
(1) He was very active ib negociating with the Nipmuks. Mrs Rowlandson notices him. In the Bk. Inds. we give his life under the name of Nepemet. See p. 105 onward.

99

cause & the Eng. inst. & hath made him very servicable & victorious since, in the war against the enemy.      One thing I shall farther mention, that is of remark "able" crossed out before I pass the history  of the matter; Joseph Tuckappawillim, minister & pastor of the ch. at Hassanamesit, before spoken of, while he was  at Boston, & before he was  sent to Deer Island, some persons had compassion on his distressd condition particularly Cap. Nicholas Page (1) & his wife (1) who took him & his childn. & his aged father to their house in Boston & refreshed their bowels with food & other comforts, & milk to preserve ye poor infants life. This poor man was much affected with & thankful for their love. While he was at  Cp. Page's, Mr. John Elliot ( his spiritual father in Christ) came to visit him with some others formerly acquainted with him & spake divers words of comfort to him suitable to his condition, divers things were spoken to him & wisely answered by him, which I shall not mention, but one passage I noted being present . Said Joseph to Mr. Elliot, O Sir said he, I am greatly distressd this day on every side, the Eng. have taken away some of my crossed out estate, my corn, cattle, my plough, cart chaire & other goods. The enemy Inds. have also taken a part of what I had, & the wicked Inds. mock & scoff at me, saying, now what is become of our praying to god. The Eng. also censure me & say I am a hypocrite. In this distress I have no where to look but up to god in Heaven
(1) A Colonel in 1689, if he be the same mentioned by Col. Church, Hist. 151, & we presume him to be. He was present at the treaty with the Narragansets in July 1675, & appears as a witness upon that instrument. There was a John of Watertown  1640, & Abraham, Boston 1665.

100
to help me now my dear wife & eldest son are (through the Eng. threatnigs) run away, & I fear will perish in the woods, for want of food, also my aged mother is lost, & all this doth greatly aggravate my grief. But yet I desire to look up to god in christ jesus in whom alone is my help. Being asked by Cap  Page whether he had not assisted the enemy in the wars when he was among them, he answered I never did join with them against the Eng. Indeed they often solicited me but I utterly denyed & refused it. I thot within myself it is better to die than to fight against the ch. of chrst. I questioned him many things of the conditn & number of the enemy he answered that he judged they were about a 1000 men, but said he, the greatest part as I conceive are for peace, & not to hold on the war, & said he, shortly they will be in great straits for food when the ground nuts are gone.
Now we come in order to declare some thing concerning the 6 Inds. that went with Mayor Savage to find out the enemy at Menumesse. There wanted not some who in their letters from the army accused Job of false dealing, & that he had informed the eny. of our army's coming agt. them. But neither the gent. (Maj Savage) nor Mr. Nowel the minister of the army intimated any such matter in their letters to the council but rather the contrary, &

101
cross out because I was not present with them to observe ye actings of those Inds. I shall content myself with writing the extract of Ms. Nowel's letter concerning the carriage & deportment of those 6 Inds. This gentlmn was the principal minister of the army, a pious & prudent person, & is minister of gods word at Boston in N. Eng. His letter was dated march 26, 1676, wherein after salutations & giving a particular account of the motions of the army from ye time they went forth until that day, saith he, I look at it as a great rebuke of god that we should miss our eny. as we did, when we were at Menumesse. If we had hearkened to those 6 Inds., whom we took from D. Isld., we might have prevented that error; they have behaved themselves like sober honest men since their abode with us, which hath made me look after them more carefully. At their first coming to Hadley the man with whom they quartered allowed them pork & peas enough, but not bread, he perceiving they had some money made them buy their bread. when they had laid out about 4s & 6d one of them told me of it, upon which I spake to the gentlema crossed outen, who ordered the constable to allow them bread, & I did give them 4/6 out of my own purse to reimburse what they had expended. And whereas some have accused Job for discovering to the Inds. our coming forth with the army I could easily demonstrate that it was not possible for

102
him to go to Menumesse to make any such discovery which he was absent from Masse?. But the circumstances of that story are so many it would be too long to commit them to writing at present. I question not Job's uprightness toward the Eng., I shall make it out if the Lord bring me back". He further adds in the same letter that the Natk.? Inds, took 2 of the enemy, which being sullen were slain, & of their advice for pursuing ye eny. which was not attended, & so the opportunity was frustrated, & several other passages he relates of them declaring their prudence & fidelity & courage. Again in another letter from ye same person dated April 9th, which was about yet time of the armys return home as for as Marbo.?, saith he "our pilots (i.e. the Inds.) were labored with to represent the way to watch where the body of the eny. quart.d very difficult before they came to speak before the council, & had ill words given them that so might be afraid to speak anything that should afford encouragement. The poor Inds. our pilots as soon as they arrived at Marbo. were much abused by the town's men, insomuch that they were unwilling to go into any house". Thus much of Mr. Nowells? letters touching those 6 Inds. of whom the unclear also gave a good character.
167 5/6. In the mouths of Feb. March & April the enemy Inds. were very violent in their attempts & assaults upon all the frontier Eng. plantations. Burning several villages(1) or part
(1)
(1) Warwick, Lancaster, Medfield, Weymouth, Groton, Marlborough, Rehoboth, Providence, & many others were among those destroyed or damaged.

103

of them, & murdering many people in the highways, (1) so that weekly, yea almost daily, messengers with sad tidings were bro't into the council, insomuch that the Lord seemed to threaten great calamity to ensue upon the Eny. nation, for none of our enterprises agt. the eny. were blessed with success, & it was groundedly  feared and judged that seed time  & harvest would be gratly obstructed & thereby occasion famine to follow the war These thiings occasion great tho'ts of heart unto the godly wise, especially such as were at the  helm of govt, & the rather because god seemed to put us to shame, & not to go forth with our arms, but to render our endeavors to quell the rage & fury of ye eny fruitless. In this conjunction of our afffairs some made application to the council to arm & send forth a compy. of the Chrn, Inds. that were at Deer Island, who had manifested themselves very desirous & willing to engage agt. the eny. in this distressing time, particularly Cap. Danl. Henchman, who was appointed by the council to look to the Inds. at Deer Isld. & to put them upon employ. This gentln. made motions to the councl. once &  again of his readiness to conduct those Indians agt. the eny., declaring that he had great confidence in god, that if they were employed they might with god's blessing be instrumental to give check to the eny. & turn the alarm, testifying that he found them very willing & desirous to serve the country, & have their parents, wives, & childn. under the Eng. power which would be rational security to the Eng. for their fidelity. But these motions were not accepted at first,for gods time was not yet come for our 
(1) "May 3, at Haverhill & Bradford, a small compy of Inds. killed two men & carried away a man & woman & five children, captive", Inll.28.

104
deliverance & the Ind. rod had not yet smarted sufficiently.  The people generally distrusted those praying Inds. & were not willing to have any of them employed to serve the council complied not with those & former motions of this nature, for many of  the council were otherwies opposed to it. Indeed afterwards the motion to arm & employ the christn. Indians was enbraced & put in practice of which we shall speak in its proper place. But some other matters previous to it were first done which I shall now relate.

Mr. Rowlandson, minister of Lancaster ( a pious & good man) having his wife, children, & severl. of his friends in captivity among the enemy, being surprised at Lancastr. as is before touched, himself & several other ministers in his behalf had some time since petitioned the council to use what means they cld. for the redemption of his wife, &c, which ye 

councill consented^ to & in pursuance thereof ordered Maj. Gookin to endeavor. to procure at Deer I. one or 2 Inds. that for a rewd. might adventr. to go with a message to the enemy to offer for the redemption of our captives particularly Mrs. Rowlandson but altho. the Maj. went to the Isld. & did his utmost endeavour to procure & crossed out an Ind. to adventr. upon this service at that time, yet cld. not prevail with them, so the matter lay dormant a good space of time but on the 23d March some friends advised Mr.  Rowlandson to make another petitin.
